Award.AwardTitle: Discovery and Description of a Megadiverse Herpetofauna
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is an intensive inventory of amphibians and reptiles of 15 major unstudied areas in Papua New Guinea (PNG), a country that occupies the eastern half of the island of New Guinea and associated archipelagos to the north. PNG has one of the richest assemblages of reptiles and amphibians in the world, with an estimated 950-1000 total species. This is twice as many species of reptiles and amphibians as North America, which is 40 times larger. Prior NSF supported work in PNG resulted in discovery of more than 120 new species of reptiles and amphibians; this new project extends surveys to include previously unexplored regions of PNG. The project also provides logistical support for a team of colleagues conducting concordant studies of herpetological parasites, mammals, birds, land snails, and aquatic insects.

The study will lead to the discovery of perhaps 120 additional new species of reptiles and amphibians, bringing our knowledge of PNG's herpetofauna to approximately 90% completion. It will document patterns of faunal richness and endemism, test biogeographic hypotheses, and identify centers of regional endemism that will advance conservation planning in the country. Finally, it will train the next generation of herpetologists working in PNG, including the first professional Papua New Guinean herpetologists, and at least two American graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the discovery and naming of new species of amphibians and reptiles and on documenting patterns of their distribution and diversity in Papua New Guinea (PNG), a country in the SW Pacific that is about the same size as California. We conducted 16 major expeditions during five years of field work throughout the country, selecting sites that were poorly known, but the basis of geographical isolation or geological history had high probabilities of producing new species. We obtained more than 6,000 specimens and tissue samples, several hundred frog call recordings, and more than 10,800 color photographs of specimens and their habitats. This resulted in the discovery and naming of 87 new species and a total of 85 scientific papers. We anticipate that on-going studies of the material that we collected will result in the naming of at least 100 additional species. Overall, our studies suggest that Papua New Guinea has around 1200 species of amphibians and reptiles. This is roughly twice the number found in the entire United States.


This project was carried out in partnership with the PNG National Museum (PNGNM). We trained and supported PNGNM staff and contributed significantly to their collections. We also worked closely with the PNG Conservation and Environmental Protection Authority (CEPA) to use our data to help guide and inform the selection of protected areas. This partnership is continuing under support from the Global Environment Facility (GEF) and from the Australian government, and we are working with CEPA to achieve the GEF project goal of adding a million hectares (nearly 4000 square miles) to the PNG's protected estate.


Our studies have also been a primary driver of a collaborative effort with the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List initiative to assess the conservation status of all species of amphibians and reptiles in Papua New Guinea. Other important collaborative efforts arising from this project include a study led by PI Allison and Prof. Shai Meiri of Tel Aviv University that is focused on the ecological and evolutionary factors that are controlling reptile diversity at world, regional and local scales. This study, funded by the Binational Science Foundation (BSF) is supporting two PhD students whose projects are based in Papua New Guinea. In addition PI Allison, in an effort that began in 2001 during a previous NSF grant and has continued under this grant, has developed the Kamiali Biological Station in collaboration with local land owners on the north coast of Papua New Guinea. This initiative has resulted in the sustainable protection of 47,000 hectares (about 120,000 acres) of rain forest and in-shore marine habitat, including coral reefs and mangroves.
